Class SelfMetaFilter

java.lang.Object
io.github.term4.echofix.SelfMetaFilter
public final class SelfMetaFilter extends Object
Configures which metadata entries are suppressed to the player it belongs to.

Modern Minecraft clients locally predict state changes (e.g. sneaking, sprinting, crawling, item use) before the server confirms them. When the server broadcasts the data back to all viewers (including the player who initiated the change), the client receives duplicate or outdated data and re-applies it, causing a one tick stutter.

This filter strips problematic entries from self-bound metadata packets. Viewers always receive the full, unmodified packet.

Usage

// Use the default filter
SelfMetaFilter filter = SelfMetaFilter.defaultPlayerFilter();

// Or build a custom filter (useful for cross version servers)
SelfMetaFilter filter = new SelfMetaFilter()
        .suppressBit((MetadataDef.Entry.BitMask) MetadataDef.IS_CROUCHING)
        .suppressIndex(MetadataDef.POSE);

  • Constructor Details

    • SelfMetaFilter

      public SelfMetaFilter()
      Creates an empty filter. Use suppressBit(MetadataDef.Entry.BitMask), suppressIndex(MetadataDef.Entry), and suppressAttributes(boolean) to configure, or use defaultPlayerFilter() for a pre-configured filter.

  • Method Details

    • suppressIndex

      public SelfMetaFilter suppressIndex(net.minestom.server.entity.MetadataDef.Entry<?> entry)
      Suppress an entire metadata index from being echoed back to self during client input processing.

      Use this for indices where the client always knows the full value, such as MetadataDef.POSE or MetadataDef.LivingEntity.LIVING_ENTITY_FLAGS.

      Parameters:
      entry - the metadata entry whose index should be suppressed
      Returns:
      this filter for chaining

    • suppressBit

      public SelfMetaFilter suppressBit(net.minestom.server.entity.MetadataDef.Entry.BitMask entry)
      Suppress specific bits within a flag byte from being echoed back to self.

      Other bits at the same index will pass through unmodified. This is used for index 0 (entity flags) where some bits are predicted locally (crouching, sprinting) and others are determined by the server (on fire, invisible, glowing, elytra flying).

      Parameters:
      entry - the bit mask entry to suppress
      Returns:
      this filter for chaining

    • suppressAttributes

      public SelfMetaFilter suppressAttributes(boolean suppress)
      Suppress EntityAttributesPacket echoes.

      When a player starts or stops sprinting (or otherwise updates certain attributes locally), the server sends an attribute update for movement speed. The client already adjusted its predicted attribute locally, so this update causes the same one tick stutter seen with certain metadata.

      Parameters:
      suppress - true to suppress attribute echoes
      Returns:
      this filter for chaining

    • suppressAttributes

      public boolean suppressAttributes()
      Returns whether attribute packet echoes should be suppressed.
      Returns:
      true if attribute packet echoes should be suppressed

    • filter

      public Map<Integer, net.minestom.server.entity.Metadata.Entry<?>> filter(Map<Integer, net.minestom.server.entity.Metadata.Entry<?>> entries)
      Filter a metadata entry map, stripping preconfigured data.

      For bit-suppressed indices, only the specified bits are removed from the flag byte; remaining bits pass through. For fully suppressed indices, the entire entry is removed.

      Parameters:
      entries - the original metadata entries from the packet
      Returns:
      a filtered copy if any entries were modified, or null if no filtering was needed (the original packet can be sent as-is)

    • defaultPlayerFilter

      public static SelfMetaFilter defaultPlayerFilter()
      Creates the default filter for player entities.

      Suppresses:

      • Crouching bit (0x02)
      • Sprinting bit (0x08)
      • Pose index
      • Living entity flags index (eating, blocking, bow draw)
      • Entity attribute echoes

      Non-predicted bits always pass through (e.g. on fire, glowing) Swimming and crawling stutter is also resolved by pose suppression (index 6) even though the swimming bit (0x10) is not explicitly filtered.

      Returns:
      a new default filter
